title: Evaluating Machine Learning for Information Extraction

author: Neil Ireson, Web Intelligence Technologies Group, Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield

segmentation: Little unlike any of the other papers I've heard in the conference so far, because everyone seems to have presented and.
The evaluation of a number of algorithms which were used on a challenge that we set as part of the Pascal Challenge.
And there were eleven groups which participated in this challenge.
As long as as well as my.
Both involved in this challenge as the local coordinator.
There were five other groups and people involved in this challenge, and who also coauthors on the paper, so it obviously just like to mention them and thank those people.
So the outline of the talk is going to be firstly setting out the challenge.
Goals why?
Why do we think that this Challenger actually had to take place or should have taken place and then look at the individual and elements which make up the challenge.

So the data which we used within the challenge, the tasks which we set the participants who the participants were and a brief description of the systems which they used and then look at the experimental results for each of the tasks.
Although I'm not sure how much time we're going to have to go through all of the tasks.
And then finally draw some conclusions at the end.
So, um.
Information extraction saw a group of challenges presented in the 90s from the message understanding conferences or conferences, but these weren't specifically aimed at machine learning.
And so the the the, the people, the participants who performed well generally presented systems with hand coded rules and lots of linguistic trickery.
So what we try to do is basically set up a challenge which was specifically aimed at the machine learning community.
Their thing was that there were a number of systems generated in the 90s for machine learning in information extraction.

But when it came to comparison, if we if we looked at the comparisons that were made, there are a number of inconsistencies within those people use different splits of the training set, the metrics they use for evaluation changed.

And it was very hard to in some cases when you read the papers, it was certain elements of the systems which they presented weren't fully explained, so they used a number of pre processing methods which weren't explicitly mentioned in the paper and those could have well had a very large impact upon the upon the final results.
So what we're looking to do is to basically create fair playing field in which to evaluate the machine learning for information extraction.
So this involved basically three areas where we standardize the data, which which we're going to.
To give to the participants, which involves standardized the partitions of the data set and also the features which we used the preprocessor to generate.
And also to make the tasks very explicit and to have an evaluation metric which everyone followed and again was very explicit.
The other thing was we wanted this work to be used in the future to be able to the the methodology to be criticized and added to.
The data that we collected for this challenge was related to the workshop call for papers.
And we collected 1100 documents.
600 of these we annotated 400 as the training set which we gave to the participants and 200.
We kept unseen for the final formal evaluation.
As you see, there's there's a chronological split between the training and the test data, so the training data occurs on and before the year 2000.
The test data on and after the year 2000.
So there's a slight overlap.
So there should be some structural differences between the test data and the training data, which was done in order to basically see how well the.
The participants models could generalize the features in the training data.
The training data was split into four sets, for which allowed their participants to do 4 fold cross validation and these were further divided into 10 sets of 10 documents which enable.
Standardized learning curve and active learning experiments.
The 500 unannotated documents were.
So provided with to the participants in order that they could use them for semi supervised learning.
As you see there's some overlap between the unannotated documents in the test data, which meant the participants could exploit the structural similarities between these two sets of data.
A further experiment basically allowed to the participants to go out into the World Wide Web and collect any data that they could.
So this gives an example of of.
Of what the documents looked like.

Slots with which to annotate the document.
Eight of these related to the workshop itself and three related to the Associated Conference.
If there was one, this is the annotation tool.
We used the.
On the right, yeah, you can see an example of a document which gives you some idea about the the annotations that were in the document.

The deadline for notification followed by actual data etc.
